title: Jordon Hudson responds to Bill Belichick’s Hall of Fame snub by sending a message to the NFL
description: Big Bill's girlfriend is planning a bash.
fullText:
Jordon Hudson responds to Bill Belichick’s Hall of Fame snub by sending a message to the NFL originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Jordon Hudson took Bill Belichick’s Pro Football Hall of Fame snub personal by planning a celebration of her own.

According to a report from People, Belichick's girlfriend is organizing a “huge bash” for the legendary coach on Aug. 8 — the same day the Pro Football Hall of Fame will induct its Class of 2026 in Canton, Ohio.

The party is expected to take place just weeks before Belichick begins his second season as the head coach at North Carolina. The event is reportedly intended as a show of support after Belichick fell one vote short of first-ballot induction, receiving 39 of the 40 votes required for election.

Hudson is expected to invite several prominent figures closely tied to Belichick’s career, including Tom Brady, Jimmy Johnson and Bill Parcells. Many of whom would have otherwise attended the ceremony in Canton. An anonymous source told People the purpose of the bash is “to celebrate alongside all of his people.”

Belichick’s omission sparked widespread reaction across the NFL world, with reports suggesting internal politics among voters may have played a role.

In response to the backlash, the Hall of Fame released a statement affirming the integrity of its selection process and noting that any violations of voting bylaws could result in disciplinary action.

Belichick, who owns eight Super Bowl rings — six as a head coach — and a 302-165 career record, has not publicly addressed the snub. His focus remains on his next chapter in college football, but Hudson ensures his legacy is celebrated anyway.

title: Bengals, Cowboys, Seahawks, 49ers dubbed top landing spots for former $22 million Pro Bowler defender
description: The Cincinnati Bengals, Dallas Cowboys, Seattle Seahawks, and San Francisco 49ers have been linked to a former Pro Bowl pass rusher in NFL free agency.
fullText:
Bengals, Cowboys, Seahawks, 49ers dubbed top landing spots for former $22 million Pro Bowler defender originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Cincinnati Bengals, Dallas Cowboys, Seattle Seahawks, and San Francisco 49ers could target a former Pro Bowl edge rusher this offseason to upgrade their defenses.

CBS Sports' Zach Pereles believes Jadeveon Clowney could have a decent market in free agency, with the Bengals, Cowboys, Seahawks, and 49ers as potential suitors.

Pereles adds his prediction of Clowney leaving Dallas to sign with Cincinnati:

"Even at 32, Clowney showed he can get after the passer and stop the run at a high level. The Bengals very much need both."

Clowney played in 13 games and started six for the Cowboys in 2025, posting 8.5 sacks and 40 quarterback pressures, proving that he can still be a valuable part of a pass-rushing rotation.

Dallas should look to retain Clowney, but if he does leave, any contender will be interested in the former No. 1 pick.

Cincinnati and San Francisco could use more pass-rushing help, especially the Bengals if they lose Trey Hendrickson. Clowney would step in as an immediate starter for the Bengals and provide solid production as a complementary pass rusher.

The 49ers could also use Clowney to pair with Nick Bosa, who will return in 2026 after playing just three games in 2025 due to a torn ACL. An edge rusher duo of Bosa and Clowney would be electric and revive a San Francisco pass rush that ranked last in the NFL in sacks this year.

Though they already have a stacked defense, don't rule out a reunion between Clowney and the Seahawks. Seattle is slated to have nearly $75 million in cap space and could upgrade its Super Bowl roster by signing Clowney to bolster the pass rush.

title: Browns 2026 NFL draft: TE Justin Joly ready for the next step
description: The Cleveland Browns need to add to their tight end room with Justin Joly an option in the 2026 NFL draft
fullText:
How is the tight end situation with the Cleveland Browns? Will quality backups be needed? Will the team look to NFL free agency, the NFL draft, or both to help the room?

Tight end Justin Joly of North Carolina State got an invite from the Senior Bowl and was thrilled that he was considered one of the best at his position. He also wanted to prove that he belonged and would make a great addition to any roster.

Joly grew up in New Rochelle, New York, and went to UConn for two years, where he led the team in receptions. He entered the final week of the regular season ranked third in FBS in both categories for tight ends.

After going 3-9-0 in 2023, he then entered the portal and took the offer from North Carolina State.

More than blessed to be on this earth for 18 years

— Justin Joly (@jjoly_17) July 9, 2022

NC State finished its 2024 season with a 9-4-0 record and one game out of first place in the conference with a 6-2-0 mark. But they couldn’t beat Notre Dame and Duke in critical conference play. However, they did thump their rival, North Carolina, 39-20.

Jolly was named First Team All-ACC after his senior season.

Dawgs by Nature staff writer Barry Shuck was at the Senior Bowl this week. He interviewed Joly during a practice session.

————————————————————————————————————————————

Shuck: You were the leading receiver at UConn, yet you left. What was the issue?

Joly: Coming out of high school, I didn’t have many offers. UConn was the best choice. After leading my team in catches, I wanted bigger opportunities and didn’t see them with UConn playing schools like Ball State, Fresno State, and Sacred Heart. I wanted bigger games with a Power-5 school. Then we only won three games, so I talked to my family and decided that, as much as I enjoyed my time at UConn and loved the coaching staff, I entered the portal. I improved my blocking and route running while at UConn. NC State, Tennessee, and Houston offered.

Shuck: You grew up in New York State, so UConn was close to home. Did that enter into your decision to end up in the State of North Carolina, where the weather and culture are so much different?

Joly: Honestly, it really didn’t matter to me. I just want to play good football. I know I’m far away from home, and my mom didn’t like that much. It’s a great place where I’m at. The culture and fanbase at NC State are great, and my coaches have a lot of respect for me and are really hyped for the season.

Shuck: How do you describe your game?

Joly: I am resilient and will fight with my brothers. I am the person who is giving 100%, 100% of the time. Just watch what you did and correct, and do whatever you got to do.

Shuck: What do you need to improve?

Joly: A little bit of everything. There’s nothing to my game, I think is perfect, nor will ever be. I would say route running, hands, and work more on blocking.  I’m a true competitor and look for every edge I can get.

Joly: My ability after the catch with good hands, blocking downfield. I am a great downfield blocker. I am good at reading and understanding defenses. And if the offense needs to play fast, I’m there for it.

Shuck: What do you learn most after a loss?

Joly: They beat us, and we beat ourselves. So, really, it was 22 versus zero. It’s hard because I hate losing. Always props to the other team, but find the issues and make corrections. Then work at it, bring the pressure, and prep for it. You have to keep your head up and maintain the good energy that we have within the facility.

Shuck: NFL teams like physical tools, and you are a former basketball player. What skills in that sport have helped you in football?

Joly: Playing a position that requires catching passes means being able to jump, and a lot of passes aren’t near where I need the ball to be, so you have to adjust and go after it. I study a lot of film and want to be on the same page as my quarterback, but sometimes the pass rush changes the pattern of the ball in flight. I am a good jumper, and with my height, I feel I can get up more than any linebacker covering me. Plus, all the running in basketball.

Shuck: You haven’t gotten the attention and respect nationally for being such a good tight end. Do you walk around with a chip on your shoulder?

Joly: Honestly, that doesn’t faze me because at the end of the day, I think my teammates know what I am capable of. And a lot of times, your job is just to block for other players to get the stats and attention. And that’s my job in that game. In the next game, I might get the most targets. I want the respect of the people in the locker room.

title: NFL salary cap to exceed $300 million, Patriots in good shape for 2026
description: The NFL has informed its clubs about the salary cap outlook for 2026.
fullText:
While the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks are preparing for their showdown in Super Bowl LX, the other 30 teams in the NFL are already in offseason mode. On Friday, the NFL shared some crucial information with all of them: the salary cap projection for the upcoming season is out.

According to a report by NFL Network’s Tom Pelissero, the league will set its spending ceiling for 2026 in the range of $301.2 million to $305.7 million per team. For comparison, the cap was set at $279.2 million for the current season.

At between 7.9% and 9.5%, the increase from 2025 to 2026 marks the latest major jump in the cap. In the five years since taking a one-year dip due to the fallout from the Covid-19 pandemic, it has grown by more than $100 million.

Despite having been among the most active team in the NFL last offseason, the Patriots are again in decent shape heading into 2026.

According to salary cap expert Miguel Benzan, who is using the middle ground of $303.45 million for his calculations, the AFC champions are currently projected to be $42.6 million under the cap with 50 players signed. This places them in the top-10 for the next league year.

New England may be less financially flexible as last spring, when the club was near the top of the table, but it still has ample resources available to maintain the quality of its roster and add outside talent. At the moment, after all, only seven of its current players are headed for unrestricted free agency, with defensive linemen Khyiris Tonga and K’Lavon Chaisson as well as safety Jaylinn Hawkins the most prominent names on the list.

title: 2026 NFL Draft: 5 Senior Bowl defensive linemen Chiefs fans must watch
description: Kansas City Chiefs fans need to check out some of the best defensive linemen from the Senior Bowl before the 2026 NFL Draft.
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs need to add depth, and maybe even a starter, along their defensive line in the 2026 NFL Draft. Fortunately, some of the best trench players in the class recently came together to compete in Mobile, Ala. for the Senior Bowl. Several prospects stood out as potential targets for the Chiefs.

According to Pro Football Focus, George Karlaftis was the only Kansas City edge rusher to amass 35 or more pressures in 2025. For reference, 59 edge rushers across the entire NFL reached that threshold. Within the AFC West, a duo of Denver Broncos, three Las Vegas Raiders and three Los Angeles Chargers accomplished the feat. Only the Chiefs lagged behind.

Future Pro Football Hall of Fame defensive tackle Chris Jones helps the Chiefs keep their noses above water in the pass rush, but he offers limited value in run defense at this stage of his career. Jones turns 32 years old before the start of the 2026 season.

The Chiefs need to add immediate production on the edge while also considering the long-term future of their interior defensive line. The Senior Bowl features enough star prospects to satisfy both needs, if the Chiefs hit on their selections.

When the 2026 Panini Senior Bowl kicks off at 1:30 p.m. CT today on NFL Network, Chiefs fans should keep an eye out for these five star defensive linemen.

Height is undersized at 6’2 3/8”, 234 lbs. with 32 3/4” arms. Those measurements didn’t stop him from dominating opposing offensive tackles during the team periods. He beat Dametrious Crownover with an outside jab into a B-gap swim and reached the quarterback in just 2.1 seconds on Wednesday. Height’s speed rush is very effective and sets up his twitchy inside counters.

Height suffered several clean losses. He struggles to win when offensive tackles get into his pads early in the play, and his limited mass makes it difficult to survive heavy punches. Height projects best as a rotational edge rusher who could develop into a full-time starter, similar to Alex Highsmith’s path on the Steelers.

Jacas, Kyle Louis and Zion Young stood at the pinnacle of performance throughout the Senior Bowl practices. At 6’3 1/8”, 260 lbs. with 32 3/4” arms, Jacas is a stout, sawed-off rusher capable of driving through the offensive tackle’s frame with power, winning around the corner with technical savvy or reducing inside to challenge guards.

Jacas won at the Senior Bowl with an outside speed rush, speed-to-power conversion, chop-rip combinations and swims through the B-gap. His explosiveness off the line of scrimmage led to several instantaneous wins.

Jacas fits the archetype of edge rusher Kansas City values. He entered the week with mixed grades. Now, it seems inconceivable that he goes anywhere later than the early third round.

Banks missed most of his final season with injuries and started off on the wrong foot in Mobile. His first day or practice was a wash, but he dominated across the final two sessions. At 6’6”, 335 lbs. with 35” arms and 10 3/4” hands, Banks is a behemoth capable of pushing the pocket or applying clean pressure by discarding guards with his violent hands.

Caleb Banks gets a win on Auburn’s Jeremiah Wright, and he’s feeling pretty good about it. #thedraftstartsinmobile #seniorbowl #nfldraft pic.twitter.com/qIbxVFIQXi

— Sam Teets (@Sam_Teets33) January 29, 2026

Banks displays rare foot quickness and agility early in plays, especially for a defender his size. His pad level becomes a limiting factor late in games, but the tradeoff seems worth it for teams hoping to add more muscle to their defensive front.

Hunter is a physical freak in his own right. He’s 6’3 1/2”, 320 lbs. with 34 1/4” arms. His rare explosiveness helps him drive vertically on pass plays, but he also possesses the quickness and lateral agility to exchange gaps or sidestep and play around blockers.

Lee Hunter is a top 50 player for me. 330-lb NT with heavy hands and a very quick first step for his size. Comfortably the most detailed and instinctive pass rusher in the '26 NT class pic.twitter.com/NC3o1WNdu9

— James Foster (@NoFlagsFilm) December 10, 2025

Hunter’s stout anchor and long arms make it easy for him to stack, peek and shed blockers in the run game. Displacing him at the point of attack is a challenging task. Hunter resets the line of scrimmage by driving blockers into the backfield and finishes big plays with his closing burst.

Hunter’s skill set and playstyle make him the perfect complement to Chris Jones. The Texas Tech product should rank near the top of Kansas City’s draft board.

Young ranked among the top performers at the Senior Bowl. He is a dense and powerful edge rusher at 6’5 1/4”, 262 lbs. with 33 1/2” arms. Throughout the week, he displayed the power to push the pocket and soften angles before finishing his rushes with counters.

The power that Missouri’s Zion Young has shown at the Senior Bowl is terrifying. You don’t want to see him lining up across from you in a four-point stance with those bent elbows. pic.twitter.com/qCksPcbCZh

— Bobby Football (@Rob__Paul) January 29, 2026

Young sent Jude Bowry tumbling in a one-on-one rep and folded J.C. Davis in one of the most dominant displays of power all week. Young primarily relies on winning through the offensive lineman’s frame or countering into or prying open the B-gap because of his lack of bend. However, his long strides help him push upfield quickly and led to some clean wins in the team periods.

Young’s arm length, play strength and anchor also make him an effective edge-setter in the run game.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs NFL Draft: Watch these 5 Senior Bowl defensive linemen

title: Mike Evans may continue playing, but will it be for the Bucs?
description: Mike Evans hasn’t had the first discussion with the Bucs about his future. There have been no conversations about 2026 with his agent, Deryk Gilmore, who is currently focused on clients in the NFL draft.
fullText:
Mike Evans hasn’t had the first discussion with the Bucs about his future. There have been no conversations about 2026 with his agent, Deryk Gilmore, who is currently focused on clients in the NFL draft.

Still, as with any pending free agent, there is going to be speculation.

Evans will be 33 by the time training camp gets underway in August. He can retire, return to play for the Bucs or take his talents elsewhere.

Evans is the greatest offensive player in franchise history, a certain future Pro Football Hall of Famer who tied Jerry Rice with an NFL-record 11 consecutive 1,000-yard receiving seasons to begin his career.

He endured six full years in Tampa Bay without so much as a whiff of the playoffs, then the Bucs won Super Bowl 55 in his first postseason.

But this season, Evans was limited to eight games by a hamstring injury and a broken clavicle. The streak died. He caught only 30 passes.

Even so, Evans proved he still had plenty of football left in the tank when he returned after eight weeks to catch six passes for a season-high 132 yards, including a 45-yard reception, in a late-season loss to Atlanta.

He showed speed, quickness and agility, and brought energy to the offense.

The first question for any player when contemplating their future is whether they still can impact the game. For Evans, it’s a resounding yes.

Quarterback Baker Mayfield hasn’t talked to Evans this offseason but predicted this past week he would continue playing and that it would be for the Bucs.

“Mike’s too much of a competitor and cares too much about Tampa to end his career without 1,000 yards, without a division championship, without a playoff run,” Mayfield said on “The Ronde Barber Show.”

New Bucs offensive coordinator Zac Robinson said Tuesday he had not spoken to Evans but wants him back. The fact Mayfield is confident in Robinson, who was the Rams’ passing game coordinator and quarterbacks coach when he spent five weeks with LA in 2022, is a plus.

“I have a ton of respect for Mike and his game throughout his career,” Robinson said. “Obviously, watching from afar, I know he’s got to work through a lot of things, but I would obviously love an opportunity to work with Mike.”

Tony Pauline of “Essentially Sports” said this week that those he’d spoken to believe there’s a less than 50-50 chance Evans would want to return to the Bucs in 2026. He suggested Evans would prefer to go to a team that has a better chance of winning a Super Bowl.

But it may be best to hear it from Evans’ own mouth.

He covered many of the same subjects in an interview with the Tampa Bay Times prior to a preseason game in Pittsburgh in August. At the time, Evans knew he was nearing the end of his career.

“This game is going to be gone, and I ain’t going to be able to do this anymore,” he said. “I know I’m not playing more than five years. Hell, maybe not more than three, we’ll see.”

Evans admitted that as he has gotten older, it’s become harder to practice.

“The games are the fun part. The games are easy. It’s training all year. I know it’s routine, but it takes a toll as you get older,” he said.

“I stay in shape. I learned that a long time ago, and I wished I’d learned it sooner. Like, my first two years, I was big. ... When you see the pictures, I have a fat face and love handles that are a little bigger. Now I give my trainer a week or two after the season. We start light, and we just build up gradually.”

Family is Evans’ biggest priority. Two years ago, his wife, Ashli, convinced him to re-sign with the Bucs for two years and $41 million. The couple have three children together: daughters Ariah Lynn and Aliyah Nicole, and son Amari Thomas, along with a stepdaughter named Mackenzie.

“It motivates me to play longer,” Evans said. “They keep me younger.”

There also is a big financial component for both the Bucs and Evans to consider.

The player who most resembles Evans in terms of production and age is Davante Adams, who signed a two-year, $44 million deal with the Rams last March. But Chris Godwin will enter the second year of a three-year, $66 million deal, and the Bucs are suddenly loaded at receiver with Evans, Godwin, Emeka Egbuka, Jalen McMillan and Tez Johnson. Of course, 2025 tested that depth.

While money won’t be what determines Evans’ future, it would be naïve to think it isn’t a factor.

“The money’s great, and I just love the game. I love to compete,“ he said. ”And while I’m blessed to still have this ability, I’m going to try to maximize it.

“I’ve got a lot of friends and family. There’s so much behind the scenes that nobody will ever know about. But that’s the other thing that motivates me. And I’m seeing the contracts and I’m like, ‘Wow, that’s crazy.’ I mean, I don’t make what Ja’Marr Chase is getting, $40 million a year? And I’m half of that. It’s still great money. It’s money you dream of making.”

The last time Evans was a free agent, he had offers from the Chiefs and Texans. Patrick Mahomes is coming off an ACL injury but is expected back by the start of the 2026 regular season. Houston is only 50 miles from Evans’ hometown of Galveston, and the Texans have a Super Bowl-caliber defense.

If Evans is merely chasing a ring, it might make more sense for him to sign with a team like Buffalo with quarterback Josh Allen or the Patriots with Drake Maye.

Retirement doesn’t seem like it will be Evans’ first choice. His kids are homeschooled, and the family splits time between Tampa and Texas.

He knows he has a few more good years left, and once you put the keys on the table it’s hard to pick them back up again.

“That’s what every athlete wants to do,” Evans said in August. “Like LeBron (James) or Tom (Brady). They wish they could do that. That’s what I’m trying to maximize. I’m not going to play 20 years, but I’m going to try to play as long as I can while I’m at the top of my game.”

At the time, Evans sounded like he wanted to keep playing. Mayfield makes some good points: He won’t want to go out playing in only eight games, catching only 30 passes and missing the playoffs.

But he needs some time and space to make a decision.

Every weekday, tune into our Sports Day Tampa Bay podcast to hear reporter Rick Stroud break down the biggest stories in Tampa Bay sports.

Never miss out on the latest with your favorite Tampa Bay sports teams. Follow our coverage on X and Facebook.

title: Where to watch Senior Bowl 2026: TV channel, live stream, time, rosters for NFL Draft prospect showcase
description: Here's how fans can watch the Senior Bowl this year.
fullText:
Where to watch Senior Bowl 2026: TV channel, live stream, time, rosters for NFL Draft prospect showcase originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The NFL offseason is about to kick into full gear, as every team is already preparing for the NFL draft in April.

One of the early steps for the draft process is the Senior Bowl, which will feature college football's best seniors in one game. For draft prospects participating, this will be their final chance to impress teams in a game setting.

The Senior Bowl always takes place in Alabama the week before the Super Bowl, and that will be no different in 2026. This year's game will feature a few notable names, including a few Heisman Trophy finalists.

Here's how fans can watch the Senior Bowl this year.

STREAM: Watch the 2025 Senior Bowl LIVE on Fubo

NFL Network will once again be broadcasting the Senior Bowl, as draft analysts Daniel Jeremiah and Charles Davis are likely on the call once again. Those looking for an alternate streaming option can use Fubo, which offers a free trial to new users.

This year's Senior Bowl will kickoff at 2:30 p.m. ET, 1:30 p.m. local time, from Hancock Whitney Stadium in Mobile, Alabama.

Fans can listen to the Senior Bowl live on SiriusXM.

title: Jesse Minter snatches rising NFL coordinator for Ravens opening
description: The Ravens are hiring a sitting offensive coordinator from an NFC playoff team.
fullText:
Jesse Minter is known for his defensive prowess, and he'll likely lean heavily on his offensive staff as he takes over his first head coaching job with the Baltimore Ravens. And now, Minter has found his offensive coordinator.

On Friday, it was announced that the Ravens will be hiring current Bears offensive coordinator Declan Doyle in the same role. Doyle does not call the plays in Chicago, with head coach Ben Johnson heavily involved in the system. Now, he will get his first opportunity as a playcaller in the NFL.

ESPN sources: the Baltimore Ravens are hiring Bears offensive coordinator Declan Doyle as their offensive coordinator. Doyle can leave because, in Baltimore, he will have play-calling responsibility. But new Ravens HC Jesse Minter now has someone to run Baltimore’s offense. pic.twitter.com/ad4iDXLjyh

— Adam Schefter (@AdamSchefter) January 30, 2026

At 29, Doyle will be the youngest offensive play-caller in the NFL with the move, and he has just seven seasons of NFL assistant experience. He helped lead a Bears offense that finished sixth in the NFL in total offense and ninth in scoring this past season, a season that saw the Bears win the NFC North for the first time since 2018 and advance to the playoffs.

Doyle was previously a tight ends coach with the Broncos from 2023-2024, and an offensive assistant with the Saints from 2019-2022. When asked on Thursday what he was looking for in his first offensive coordinator, Minter said that he was "looking for a connector and an innovator, and a scheme builder around the best player in the world."

This article originally appeared on Touchdown Wire: Jesse Minter snatches rising NFL coordinator for Ravens opening

title: Browns become first team in NFL history to accomplish an odd task
description: The Browns have become the first team in NFL history to have two quarterbacks from their opening day roster named to a Pro Bowl in the same season
fullText:
The Cleveland Browns have set a new and unusual mark from their extremely uninspiring 2025 season.

Despite winning just five games, the Browns have become the first team in NFL history to have two quarterbacks from the opening day roster to be named as Pro Bowlers. This comes after both Shedeur Sanders and Joe Flacco were late additions to the Pro Bowl roster.

Sanders was added to the games earlier this week, while Flacco was added on Friday afternoon. Flacco, of course, was the Browns' opening weekend starter. He was then benched for Dillon Gabriel and subsequently traded in-division to the Cincinnati Bengals after the injury to their star quarterback Joe Burrow. Flacco went on to light it up through the air despite a lack of overall wins in Cincinnati.

So, there will be a small Cleveland reunion at the Pro Bowl games, where Flacco and Sanders can catch up with one another after one of the weirdest seasons imaginable for both of them.

This article originally appeared on Browns Wire: Browns become first team in NFL history to accomplish an odd task

title: Patriots Issue Game Statuses Before Departing For Super Bowl
description: The New England Patriots played it right down the middle on Friday. The NFL required both participants to issue projected game statuses for Super Bowl LX, with the local club choosing to list all nine players on their injury report — quarterback Drake Maye (shoulder/illness), running back Terrell Jennings (hamstring), tight end Hunter Henry (rest), […]
fullText:
The New England Patriots played it right down the middle on Friday.

The NFL required both participants to issue projected game statuses for Super Bowl LX, with the local club choosing to list all nine players on their injury report — quarterback Drake Maye (shoulder/illness), running back Terrell Jennings (hamstring), tight end Hunter Henry (rest), defensive lineman Joshua Farmer (hamstring), wide receiver Mack Hollins (abdomen), linebackers Harold Landry III (knee) and Robert Spillane (ankle), and offensive lineman Thayer Munford Jr. (knee/illness) and Morgan Moses (rest) — as questionable.

Maye, who reportedly suffered a shoulder injury during his club’s victory over the Denver Broncos in the AFC Championship, was listed as a limited participant on the injury report Thursday and a non-participant on the injury report Friday.

Maye would have practiced if not for his newfound illness, however, as stated by head coach Mike Vrabel.

Landry, Spillane and Munford are the three most doubtful players to play in the big game, as none participated in practice this week. Henry, Hollins and Moses are expected to be available.

The Patriots and Seahawks’ projected game statuses are listed below:

title: I'm an NFL mom navigating huge money and pressure. There is no guidebook, so I'm helping other parents through it.
description: Twanna Harris explains the emotional and financial challenges of parenting NFL athletes and why she founded League of Industry Moms.
fullText:
This as-told-to essay is based on a conversation with Twanna Harris, the founder of League of Industry Moms. It has been edited for length and clarity.

I'm a mom to two athletes. Between my husband and me, we have four kids, two sons and two daughters. William, my oldest, has played for the Washington Commanders for seven years. My son Trey is what we call our "next kid up." He is at Sam Houston State University, and he's started training for the NFL draft.

My husband played in the NFL, so I believe our family is uniquely equipped to navigate this process and provide structure and discipline.

However, there were things that surprised me, even though I was not expecting them.

Injuries are actually the last thing I'm worried about.

I am the one who has guided my sons to where they are today. I researched programs, coordinated the move to other schools when necessary, identified trainers, researched colleges that provide the best opportunity, and provided the necessary financial, emotional, and mental support to properly navigate the transition from high school to college, in preparation for making it to the pros.

When going through that transition, I felt like the sentiment was, "Thanks so much for your contribution, but we'll take it from here." There weren't conversations with us parents about how to navigate and sustain salaries once they went pros, for example.

Additionally, I didn't get any coaching or direction on how to choose the best advisor or counsel for your athlete's specific situation.

I helped one of my sons go through a rough patch, which had isolating moments, and I knew I couldn't be the only mother trying to figure this out by myself. This drove my desire for community, and after speaking with numerous mothers of athletes, I quickly realized that what I experienced was more of the norm than the exception.

Because there's no blueprint or guidebook, I launched my collective, League of Industry Moms, to crowdsource support and resources to help us navigate this terrain together.

We look into everything from media training to financial literacy, such as how kids should set up their finances for when they are 50, and helping them understand the significance of their spending for the next five years.

Typically, a kid is not celebrated daily for their job. But because my kids are athletes, they are — and are receiving death threats at the same time. Nothing feels real anymore, and it feels like everyone's coming to get a piece of your child. One day, we're in this together as a family, and the next, your kid is saying, "Hey Mom, I'm an adult now, I don't need your permission to take a $425,000 check."

Because they are legally adults, there's no requirement for brands to speak with parents. There can be a false sense of reality here because, early on, players receive a substantial amount of resources, attention, and money. There's no player association or union, so I've partnered with an organization called athletes.org to make sure we are educating parents going through this.

My husband and I have raised our kids to be extraordinarily independent. The whole point is to raise kids to be self-sufficient, but this is a different kind of survival. Someone whose frontal lobe has yet to develop is being handed a check for millions, and they are expected to have the wherewithal to know what to do with that.

The most important thing my husband and I wanted to teach our athletes is the art of listening and the discernment gained through that process to detect when someone might be motivated by the wrong intentions or when something they are saying simply doesn't sound right.

title: The NFL's 'Queen's Gambit' who helped create $1.5bn worth of talent
description: Coach and consultant Duane Manyweather has worked with some of NFL's best players in one of the sport's most undervalued positions.
fullText:
When you think of the NFL's biggest names, not many are players in the offensive line.

It's an unfashionable position, yet these players hold one of the most important roles in the team and are often unsung heroes in Super Bowl-winning sides.

Duane Manyweather has made a name for himself as a 'super coach' for the position, having nurtured stars who have gone on to make career earnings north of $1.5bn (£1.1bn).

Those players include New England Patriots offensive tackle Will Campbell, picked fourth in the NFL Draft in April and now set to make his Super Bowl debut next week.

What makes Manyweather's coaching so successful? Well he compares his thought process to Anya Taylor-Joy's character in the Netflix hit The Queen's Gambit. She is cast as a talented female chess player, who could envision future moves on the board in real time.

"When I'm watching football, the best way that I describe it [is like] The Queen's Gambit," Manyweather tells BBC Sport. "My wife said that how all the moves would go on the ceiling at night, how the player would see it [in the TV show], that's kind of how I see it."

title: Tom Brady Narrates AMC Docuseries on the 49ers’ Golden Era
description: AMC’s Rise of the 49ers takes fans inside the legendary NFL franchise that defined dominance in the 1980s and early ’90s.
fullText:
If you're bummed that the San Francisco 49ers are not in the Super Bowl, you can relive their glory days with the docuseries Rise of the 49ers, which will premiere with the first two episodes on Sunday, Feb. 1, at 9 pm ET/PT and then with the final two episodes debuting on Monday, Feb. 2 at 9 pm ET/PT on AMC and AMC+. Narrated by Executive Producer Tom Brady, the series chronicles the rise and dominance of the San Francisco 49ers during the ‘80s and early ’90s.

Footage uncovered by NFL Films, including video of team speeches and behind-the-scenes photos of San Francisco’s legendary head coach Bill Walsh, will tell the story of how the Niners rose from being underdogs into one of the most historic franchises in the NFL.

Team legends such as Joe Montana, Jerry Rice, Steve Young, Ronnie Lott, and Eddie DeBartolo Jr. reflect on their time with the Niners and how they contributed to creating the legacy of winning five Super Bowls.

The docuseries is an AMC Studios and Skydance Sports co-production with producing partners NFL Films and Religion of Sports (ROS). Directed by Ryan Kelly, executive producers include Jesse Sisgold, Jason T. Reed and Jon Weinbach from Skydance Sports, Ross Ketover, Keith Cossrow, Ken Rodgers and Jessica Boddy from NFL Films, and Tom Brady, Gotham Chopra, Ameeth Sankaran and Victor Buhler from Religion of Sports.

A trailer for the series can be seen here.

title: Broncos pass game coordinator/QB coach Davis Webb is withdrawing from consideration for Raiders head coaching job
description: According to ESPN’s lead NFL insider, Adam Schefter, Denver Broncos pass game coordinator/quarterbacks coach Davis Webb is withdrawing from consideration for the Las Vegas Raiders head coaching job. Webb has had several offensive coordinator requests recently and is a prime candidate to become the Denver Broncos offensive coordinator, according to NFL Network insider Ian Rapoport. […]
fullText:
According to ESPN’s lead NFL insider, Adam Schefter, Denver Broncos pass game coordinator/quarterbacks coach Davis Webb is withdrawing from consideration for the Las Vegas Raiders head coaching job.

Webb has had several offensive coordinator requests recently and is a prime candidate to become the Denver Broncos offensive coordinator, according to NFL Network insider Ian Rapoport.

Broncos passing game coordinator Davis Webb is withdrawing from consideration from the Raiders head coaching job, per source. Webb interviewed for head coaching jobs with the Raiders, Bills and Ravens. pic.twitter.com/4FYpPGQ0MX

— Adam Schefter (@AdamSchefter) January 30, 2026

Davis Webb was considered a favorite for the Las Vegas Raiders head coaching job, but all signs point to them favoring Seattle Seahawks offensive coordinator Klint Kubiak instead. Both the Cardinals and the Raiders are waiting until this weekend to meet with him in hopes of hiring him after the Super Bowl. With the writing on the wall and likely not wanting to be the backup option, Webb withdrew his name from consideration.

With Webb officially out of the Raiders’ head coaching search, he becomes one of the hottest offensive coordinator names currently on the market. Several teams, including the Baltimore Ravens, New York Giants, and Philadelphia Eagles (before they hired their OC earlier today) have already put in requests to interview Webb for their offensive coordinator positions. Also, his current team, the Denver Broncos, fired offensive coordinator Joe Lombardi and would like to promote Webb to offensive coordinator if possible.

It remains to be seen if Webb will interview with the Ravens, Giants, or any other teams for their offensive coordinator jobs. He has impressed in interviews, is viewed as an up-and-coming coach, and is well-liked and regarded around the league so it would make sense for teams to be interested. However, with the Broncos firing Lombardi and opening up their offensive coordinator position, you have to assume there is mutual interest between the two sides and that the Broncos are the favorites to land him as their offensive coordinator.

Webb would benefit from another year under Sean Payton and would get more valuable experience as his offensive coordinator. While he may not call plays, he would be in the booth, communicating with Payton throughout the game, and would be a key part of game-planning each week.

There is no guarantee that Webb will return to the Broncos, as other teams can and likely will offer him play-calling opportunities, but I believe they will make a strong push for him. This should unfold in the coming days, and hopefully, Webb returns to the Broncos, this time, as their offensive coordinator.

title: 3 Lone Star standouts at Senior Bowl who fit Cowboys plans
description: The Dallas Cowboys are looking for defensive players they can pick up in the 2026 NFL draft and these Senior Bowl standouts ae great options
fullText:
While the top two teams in the NFL prepare for the Super Bowl, the Dallas Cowboys and 29 other squads are firmly fixated on talent acquisition. From coaching staff to free agency to the 2026 NFL draft, the Cowboys are treasure hunting.

Midway through Senior Bowl week, some draft hopefuls are standing out amongst their peers. The hope for Cowboys fans is that some of these standouts are at positions of need for Dallas. The Cowboys need to add players at linebacker, defensive end, safety, offensive tackle and cornerback, just to name a few. As luck would have it, some of those players are indeed flashing in practice.

Early standout reports have highlighted the defensive ends who have been jumping off the screen. The one’s mentioned here at Cowboys Wire have continued their strong play and should firmly be on Dallas’ radar this April. Today we look at three more.

Bud Clark has been turning heads here at the midpoint. The 6-foot-1, 185-pound safety from TCU was an intriguing prospect from the start. Over the past two seasons, he’s scored the third best film grade in the country. Despite a diminutive stature, Clark has been showing up as a run defender in the box, putting to bed some size concerns about his jump to the NFL.

Clark has been making plays on the ball in coverage and filling gaps against the run, proving to be a do-it-all defensive back. In 2023 he played 393 snaps in the slot, but over the last two seasons he’s mixed it up evenly between slot, box and deep.

Clark is the ideal candidate to replace free agent Donovan Wilson for the Cowboys because he can be moved everywhere including a nickel role. Clark is rocketing up draft boards and should move into the top 100 (currently a consensus rank of 185)

Death, taxes, Bud Clark making plays at the Senior Bowl.

TCU safety has been a star all week. pic.twitter.com/nm3nZWRlwP

— Max Chadwick (@CFBMaxChadwick) January 29, 2026

Jacob Rodriguez has proven he’s every bit as advertised. The Tech standout has been everywhere on the field, picking off balls in coverage and punching out balls in the open field. In this extremely deep LB class, Rodriguez is a star.

Physical traits stand to hold him back on draft boards, but the kid is a mental giant who just makes plays. Rodriguez has set the bar at the LB position scoring the highest PFF score all time amongst Power-4 LB prospects. Given he’ll probably be a Day 2 pick, he’s going to be a steal for someone this year.

Texas Tech’s Jacob Rodriguez had an all-time performance for a LB on Day 2 of the Senior Bowl. 

Not only did he show off his peanut punch with a forced fumble, but he also had an INT to end the day and was the best LB in coverage in one-on-ones pic.twitter.com/W8yEm4F2k7

— Bobby Football (@Rob__Paul) January 29, 2026

At just under 6-foot and weighing 183 pounds, Malik Mohammad isn’t the typical tall CB the Cowboys are attracted to but he’s making it up in tenacity and stickiness at the Senior Bowl. Quick and fluid, Muhammad has shown he can stay with any build, both outside and inside.

The Cowboys are in the market for a new CB with inside ability. They felt the loss of Jourdan Lewis immensely and this prospect appears to be a great replacement option.

Malik Muhammad continues to stack good rep after good rep pic.twitter.com/AQNk9J2Poz

— TJ Wengert (@TJWengert) January 28, 2026

You can follow Reid on X @ReidDHanson and be sure to follow Cowboys Wire on Facebook to join in on the conversation with fellow fans!

This article originally appeared on Cowboys Wire: Midway checkpoint: 3 local Senior Bowl standouts who fit the Cowboys

title: Here are the latest updates on Davis Webb, Vance Joseph and Jim Leonhard
description: Broncos assistant coaches Davis Webb, Vance Joseph and Jim Leonhard are all drawing interest from NFL clubs.
fullText:
The Las Vegas Raiders will interview Seattle Seahawks offensive coordinator Klint Kubiak over the weekend before making a head coach decision, according to ESPN's Jeremy Fowler.

One source told Fowler that “it’s probably (Kubiak’s) job to lose.”

Denver Broncos offensive pass game coordinator and quarterbacks coach Davis Webb is also a candidate for the Las Vegas job, and it appears that it might be down to Kubiak and Webb. If the Raiders end up hiring Kubiak, Webb will have plenty of offensive coordinator offers.

The Baltimore Ravens, Philadelphia Eagles and New York Giants all requested OC interviews with Webb, and he will presumably be a candidate for Denver's own OC opening after the team fired Joe Lombardi.

In addition to Las Vegas, the Arizona Cardinals are also yet to hire a head coach, and Broncos defensive coordinator Vance Joseph is a candidate (but perhaps not the favorite) for that position. Arizona also plans to interview Kubiak this weekend, and he seems to be the top candidate for both openings. If Kubiak ends up with the Raiders, it's possible that Joseph could still be in play for the Cardinals.

Meanwhile, Denver assistant head coach and defensive pass game coordinator Jim Leonhard interviewed for the Los Angeles Chargers' defensive coordinator role before L.A. hired Chris O'Leary. Leonhard is believed to be a top candidate for the Buffalo Bills' DC opening, and the Baltimore Ravens have requested a DC interview with him.

If Joseph does land the HC job in Arizona, Leonhard would presumably be a top in-house candidate to replace him with the Broncos. As it stands now, though, Joseph does not appear to be the clear favorite for the Cards' job, and Leonhard will have no shortage of suitors with DC openings.

Social: Follow Broncos Wire on Facebook and Twitter/X! Did you know: These 25 celebrities are Broncos fans.

title: What Josh McDaniels Told Drake Maye To Seal Patriots’ AFC Championship
description: The New England Patriots are going to the Super Bowl, and contrary to what many of their critics have been saying this year, it wasn’t easy. While their regularseason schedule was historically soft, the Patriots had to go through three top-five defenses in the playoffs. No other team since the AFL-NFL merger in 1970 has […]
fullText:
The New England Patriots are going to the Super Bowl, and contrary to what many of their critics have been saying this year, it wasn’t easy.

While their regularseason schedule was historically soft, the Patriots had to go through three top-five defenses in the playoffs. No other team since the AFL-NFL merger in 1970 has ever done that.

What’s more, New England had to win three outdoor games in winter conditions, which got progressively worse throughout January. By the second half of the AFC title game against the Denver Broncos, the Patriots were basically playing in a blizzard.

The elements, tough defenses and pressure seemed to get to Drake Maye a bit, whose performance suffered in the postseason compared to his MVP-caliber regular season. These were the first true challenges of his career in just his second NFL season and first postseason run, and he was learning the hard way.

Drake Maye: "It's hard… Good God"

Josh McDaniels: "Look at me, it's gonna be hard, but look, this will be the most rewarding 6 1/2 minutes of our lives if we can get it done." 🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥

The vulnerability here… holy moly man. 

🎥: @Patriots pic.twitter.com/CyoaTUQpti

— Michael Rodnick (@MJRodnick) January 28, 2026

“Hey, it’s hard,” he told New England’s offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels late in the fourth quarter of Sunday’s game as snow rained down on them in Denver.

McDaniels, who’s in his 19th season with the Patriots coaching staff, is well aware. He’s been part of countless playoff games in tough conditions and is going to his ninth Super Bowl.

Fortunately for New England, he was able to help calm Maye down and give him some wise advice.

“I know,” McDaniels said, laughing. “Listen to me. Look at me. It’s gonna be hard, but look, this will be the most rewarding six and a half minutes of our lives if we can get it done.”

Maye took those words to heart, buckling down and finishing the job himself. He sealed the Patriots’ 10-7 win by running through the snow for a first down after the two-minute warning, punching their tickets to the Super Bowl.

Patriots Predicted To Add Tight End Coming Off Eight-Touchdown Year

title: Patriots Predicted To Add Tight End Coming Off Eight-Touchdown Year
description: The New England Patriots are getting ready for the Super Bowl, but the offseason is around the corner and they need to be prepared when the time comes. Whether the Patriots win the Super Bowl or not, they will have needs to address this offseason. The NFL Draft and free agency will both present option […]
fullText:
The New England Patriots are getting ready for the Super Bowl, but the offseason is around the corner and they need to be prepared when the time comes.

Whether the Patriots win the Super Bowl or not, they will have needs to address this offseason. The NFL Draft and free agency will both present option to better the team, and they could be in the market for another pass catcher.

Stefon Diggs and Mack Hollins have been great additions, but the Patriots could benefit from adding a weapon who can make plays after the catch. Drake Maye ranked outside of the top 10 in passing yards after the catch, meaning there is room to improve.

Yahoo Sports’ Nate Tice predicted the Patriots would draft University of Oregon tight end Kenyon Sadiq with the 31st pick of the NFL Draft.

“While Sadiq is a tight end, the Patriots need pass catchers, especially ones who can create explosives with the ball in their hands,” Tice wrote on Tuesday. “Offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels loves to use tight ends, and Maye has loved throwing the ball to Hunter Henry in his first two seasons. Sadiq would give them a weapon who can turn those screens and underneath routes into big plays. He has the speed and receiving ability to stretch the defense, and also some real grit as a blocker that Mike Vrabel would love.”

Sadiq had 560 yards on 51 receptions last season. He scored eight touchdowns as well. In three seasons at Oregon, he had 892 yards and 11 receiving touchdowns. He averaged 11.2 yards per reception in college.

He led Oregon in receiving touchdowns and was third on the team in receiving yards per game. At 6-foot-3, 245 pounds, he may be undersized for a tight end, but he has tremendous speed and can be a difference maker for the Patriots.

What Josh McDaniels Told Drake Maye To Seal Patriots’ AFC Championship

title: NFL Writer Suggests Former Steelers Quarterback Might Be Moved This Offseason
description: Former Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Justin Fields could be finding a new NFL home this offseason. The New York Jets inked a two-year, $40 million contract with Fields this offseason, but his performance this season was far from stellar. In nine games, he threw for 1,259 yards and only 7 touchdowns. New York will likely be […]
fullText:
Former Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Justin Fields could be finding a new NFL home this offseason.

The New York Jets inked a two-year, $40 million contract with Fields this offseason, but his performance this season was far from stellar. In nine games, he threw for 1,259 yards and only 7 touchdowns.

New York will likely be looking for a new starting quarterback this offseason, and CBS Sports NFL writer Joel Corry thinks the Jets could move Fields this offseason.

“The Jets signed Fields to a two-year, $40 million deal with $30 million fully guaranteed as an unrestricted free agent last March in the hopes that he would be more than a bridge quarterback,” Corry wrote on Wednesday. “Fields’ preseason struggles were dismissed rather than seen as a warning sign after he played well against the Pittsburgh Steelers in the regular season opener.

“It was downhill for the 2021 first-round pick after the Steelers game. Fields had a dubious distinction in a Week 6 loss to the Broncos. He was sacked nine times in producing a franchise-worst minus-10 net passing yards. Fields was benched nine games into the season.”

There’s a possibility that the Steelers could reunite with Fields this offseason, especially if Aaron Rodgers doesn’t come back. They will be in the market for a quarterback.

More NFL: Former Steelers Star Placed At No. 2 In ESPN’s Free-Agent Rankings

title: Donald Trump blasts mind-boggling Bill Belichick Hall of Fame snub
description: The sitting US President went off on Belichick's HOF omission and the 'sissy" NFL kickoff rules in a Wednesday post on Truth Social.
fullText:
You'll be hard-pressed to find a large majority of Americans who agree with one another on the same subject in 2026, but the Bill Belichick's Hall of Fame snub seems to be doing just that – and even the ever-divisive President of the United States is weighing in on the matter.

Donald Trump took to Truth Social on Wednesday to share his thoughts on Belichick after he was snubbed from the 2026 Pro Football Hall of Fame class. Belichick, a 29-year NFL head-coaching veteran with six Super Bowl rings, was considered a first-ballot selection by most fans. Still, we learned on Tuesday that he did not receive enough votes to be inducted in his first year of eligibility.

Trump is considered a rather controversial figure these days, but his opinion on the matter seemed to be right in line with most of the NFL fanbase as he blasted the decision on social media. He also took shots in the same post at what he describes as the 'sissy' kickoff rule, referring to the new Dynamic Kickoff Rule implemented by the league ahead of the 2024 season.

𝗕𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴: President Donald Trump went OFF on the NFL voters defending his close friend Bill Belichick should've been a first ballot Hall of Famer.

“It is the same mindset that gave pro football the unwatchable 'Sissy' Kickoff Rule, that made it possible for Bill to not… pic.twitter.com/qMwbJcJmCH

— Dov Kleiman (@NFL_DovKleiman) January 28, 2026

“It is the same mindset that gave pro football the new and unwatchable ‘Sissy’ Kickoff Rule, that made it possible for Bill Belichick to not be elected into the Pro Football Hall of Fame,” Trump wrote Wednesday. “Both are ridiculous and should be overturned!”

It is not Trump's first time criticizing moves regarding the NFL and its personnel, calling the new kickoff rule 'ridiculous' in 2025. Recently, Trump announced he wouldn't attend Super Bowl LX in San Francisco because it is "too far away," while blasting the scheduled musical performances by Bad Bunny and Green Day.

“I’m anti-them. I think it’s a terrible choice. All it does is sow hatred. Terrible,” Trump said.

This article originally appeared on Touchdown Wire: Donald Trump blasts mind-boggling Bill Belichick Hall of Fame snub
